  • Element
de.schenk.jrtrace.annotations

Annotation Type XClass


  • @Retention(value=CLASS)
@Target(value=TYPE)
public @interface XClass
    Terms:

    The framework will work with a "target" java application and provides the ability to inject method calls into methods of the target java application (into "target methods" of "target classes").

    The classes and methods that are inserted into the target application are referred to as the "injected classes" or "injected methods".

    The XClass annotation annotates classes that contain methods that should be injected into other java classes.

    The current injection strategy will create one Class and one instance of this class for each ClassLoader and use the respective Class and instance for injection. So all target classes that share a ClassLoader will also share a Class and an instance of this class.

    Author:
    Christian Schenk

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      java.lang.String[] classes 
      java.lang.String classloadername 
      XClassLoaderPolicy classloaderpolicy 
      boolean derived 
      java.lang.String[] exclude 
      boolean regex 

    • Element Detail

      • classes

        public abstract java.lang.String[] classes
        Returns:
        This annotation can specify one ore more fully qualified classnames. Only target classes or interfaces that match one of these classnames are potential targets for code injection from this class. Which classes qualify as targets for injection can also be influenced using the annotation derived().

        If not set, this class will not inject any code. An XClass might still be useful, since it can be used by other code injected and the classloaderpolicy() attribute can be used to specify the ClassLoader that will be used for it.

        Default:
        ""

      • classloaderpolicy

        public abstract XClassLoaderPolicy classloaderpolicy
        Returns:
        the injected class can be loaded with different ClassLoaders. See XClassLoaderPolicy for a description of the available options. Depending on this option, injected code will be loaded with different ClassLoaders. The default is to load the class with a classloader that can access the bootclasspath only.

        Example: 

        

        

        Default:
        

        de.schenk.jrtrace.annotations.XClassLoaderPolicy.BOOT
        

        

        • 

      




        

      • 

        classloadername
        

        public abstract java.lang.String classloadername
        

        Returns:
        if XClassLoaderPolicy.NAMED is selected the name of a class has to be specified. The ClassLoader
 of this class will be the used for the injected code.
        

        

        Default:
        

        ""
        

        

        • 

      




        

      • 

        derived
        

        public abstract boolean derived
        

        Returns:
        if derived is set to true, all classes that are derived from the
         classes or interfaces specified in classes() become
         potential targets for code injection.
        

        

        Default:
        

        false
        

        

        • 

      




        

      • 

        regex
        

        public abstract boolean regex
        

        Returns:
        if set to true, regular expressions will be used to test
         classnames, methodnames and argument names.
         
         
        
         Example:
         
        
         
        @XClass(classes="org\\.eclipse.*",regex=true)
        
         Methods from this Class maybe injected in all classes from the namespace org.eclipse
        

        

        Default:
        

        false
        

        

        • 

      




        

      • 

        exclude
        

        public abstract java.lang.String[] exclude
        

        Returns:
        a collection of regular expressions. All classes matching will be excluded from potential instrumentation from
 this XClass. Note that this is always a regular expression and the regex() flag has no influence here.
        

        

        Default:
        

        ""
        

        

        •
